section.name: Renderers
section.p: Apache log4php can log more than just string messages. If you try to log an object it will be converted to a string and logged. The component which converts Objects to strings in log4php is called a renderer.

subsection.name: Default renderer
subsection.p: For example, let's say that an application uses a Person object, like this one:
Log4php will render it using the default renderer and you will end the output will look something like:
subsection.pre: INFO - Here comes the person: INFO - Person::__set_state(array( 'firstName' => 'John', 'lastName' => 'Doe', 'age' => 37, ))

subsection.name: Creating a custom renderer
subsection.p: In order to make log4php render our Person object in a more readable format, we need to create a custom renderer class which will convert Person objects to a string suitable for logging.
Let's call our renderer class PersonRenderer.
Now log4php has to be configured to use PersonRenderer for rendering Person objects. This is done in the configuration file.
If the same code is run as above, the following output is produced:
subsection.pre: INFO - Here comes the person: INFO - John Doe (37)
subsection.p: Which is much more readable than the default rendering.

subsection.name: Class hierarchy
subsection.p: Object rendering follows the class hierarchy.

For example, if there is a class named Fruit, and classes Orange, Lemon and Apple all extend Fruit. When FruitRenderer is registered as renderer for the Fruit class, all subclasses of Fruit will also be rendered by FruitRenderer. Of course, it is possible to override this by registering OrangeRenderer as renderer for the Orange class.
